channel.title: APN Key Highlights Feed
channel.description: Condensed weekly summary from APN's operational report.

item.title: Meeting Participants and Invitations
item.description: Participants: Mr. Rye, Mr. Archer (present in the call), Anthony (invited), Micah, Eric, Scott, Katrina, Noah, Paul, Sarah, Emily Cronin, Jessica, Anna, and Lance (all mentioned in the discussion).

item.title: Meeting Participants and Invitations
item.description: Decision to invite Anthony to the call and include him in regular interactions, including a standing call, to align on cash projections and future business forecasting.

item.title: Meeting Participants and Invitations
item.description: Plan to schedule daily stand-up calls to ensure the team stays on the same page, receives necessary support, and identifies if anything is going off track.

item.title: Cash Flow and Forecasting
item.description: Cash flow visibility: Daily updates showed an increase from $31K to $39K, which was not considered "very good"; a drop in collections was attributed to a holiday.

item.title: Cash Flow and Forecasting
item.description: Micahâ€™s machine learning model predicts insurance cash flows for existing business with historical accuracy within 5% of actual collections. This model is granular, analyzing average DSO by payer and prefix.

item.title: Cash Flow and Forecasting
item.description: The RefRec template is now being used 100% of the time in Sage, enabling more accurate RefRec forecasts instead of relying solely on rolling averages.

item.title: P&L and General Ledger (GL) Taxonomy
item.description: Noted confusion in the P&L due to summing many numbers and grouped GL buckets, requiring review.

item.title: P&L and General Ledger (GL) Taxonomy
item.description: A taxonomy has been created to:

item.title: P&L and General Ledger (GL) Taxonomy
item.description: Classify client accounts by priority (e.g., client safety, regulatory) to guide payment prioritization.

item.title: Closing Deadlines and Payment Scheduling
item.description: Target dates for closing accounts: A business day deadline (around the 10th or 15th) was discussed, with final closure agreed upon with Eric by the 20th. The team is in a good position to beat the 20th.

item.title: Closing Deadlines and Payment Scheduling
item.description: Need for a method-based Accounts Payable (AP) process to prevent overpayment (e.g., avoiding a single $300K vendor payment). The goal is to establish a governing document for AP by the next quarter.

item.title: Closing Deadlines and Payment Scheduling
item.description: Emphasis on rapid closure ("faster is better") to proactively address potential cash shortfalls.

item.title: System Integrations and Data Management
item.description: NetSuite will serve as the source of truth for 2024 financial records, a time-intensive process estimated at four hours per site for December data alone (12 months x 9 locations).

item.title: System Integrations and Data Management
item.description: Effort to transcribe recent messages and current discussions for record-keeping and future reference.

item.title: System Integrations and Data Management
item.description: SAGE and LBMC discussed:

item.title: Accruals, Revenue Recognition, and Forecast Adjustments
item.description: Noah prefers accrual based on average in-network rates, but this method has led to significant discrepancies (never within 30%) compared to actual cash collections, making board meetings feel like a "magic show."

item.title: Accruals, Revenue Recognition, and Forecast Adjustments
item.description: Debate on using actual cash collections versus standard accruals:

item.title: Accruals, Revenue Recognition, and Forecast Adjustments
item.description: The variety in insurance payments (e.g., United Healthcare) complicates accrual accuracy.

item.title: Staffing and Resource Allocation
item.description: Proposal to add two or three additional staff ("Scots" or similar) to support cash flow reconciliation and revenue tracking.

item.title: Staffing and Resource Allocation
item.description: Plan to leverage Scottâ€™s expertise for cash reconciliation, then transition him to revenue and bad debt management.

item.title: Staffing and Resource Allocation
item.description: The finance function is under-resourced, likened to having "too many chiefs and not enough Indians."

item.title: Human Resources and Vendor/Employee Documentation
item.description: Tax documentation issues (W-9s and W-2s):

item.title: Human Resources and Vendor/Employee Documentation
item.description: Several employees reported discrepancies, such as having the wrong W-2, only one W-2, or multiple W-2s (e.g., Katrina received two W-2s and a corrected W-2).

item.title: Human Resources and Vendor/Employee Documentation
item.description: Resolution: The issue stemmed from Lance's failure to close out the previous system before PayCore. PayCore issued W-2s for the first quarter, which were superseded by corrected W-2s, and to the company's knowledge, all employees should now have the correct forms.

item.title: Additional Financial and Operational Considerations
item.description: Detailed review of revenue buckets: The four main buckets are private pay, insurance payments, paid to subscriber (PTS), and inside sales/extensions. Insurance and private pay are the largest.

item.title: Additional Financial and Operational Considerations
item.description: Extensions and inside sales revenues are tracked using a client taxonomy: P1 (private pay, no discount), P2 (private pay, some discount), I-1 (good insurance rate/deductibles paid), I-2 (barely scraping by), and scholarship. This taxonomy will eventually help predict revenue based on census data, but it will take about six months to flesh out. PTS can be volatile.

item.title: Additional Financial and Operational Considerations
item.description: Expense management: Accurate future expense projections are crucial for APN, which is currently distressed. The goal is to reduce recurring expenses to below $4 million (currently $4.2 million), acknowledging that expenses increase with growth.

item.title: ðŸ“… Next Steps and Action Items
item.description: [ ] Verify all employees have received the correct W-2s.

item.title: ðŸ“… Next Steps and Action Items
item.description: [ ] Revisit accrual revenue methodology and consider developing high/mid/low P&L scenarios, addressing concerns about investor transparency.

item.title: ðŸ“… Next Steps and Action Items
item.description: [ ] Schedule a follow-up call between Anthony and Eric to review year-to-date revenue performance and understand Eric's past methods.

item.title: Client Engagement & Calculator
item.description: Nicole met with Jeremy yesterday.

item.title: Client Engagement & Calculator
item.description: Nicole secured the client "Superbar."

item.title: Client Engagement & Calculator
item.description: Jeremy mentioned training on using a specific calculator.

item.title: SharePoint Site & Organizational Structure
item.description: Site names may need to align with the 68 simplified job titles.

item.title: SharePoint Site & Organizational Structure
item.description: There is an existing SharePoint site, and a SharePoint meeting is scheduled for noon.

item.title: SharePoint Site & Organizational Structure
item.description: The discussion focused on establishing the minimum required number of SharePoint sites to ensure comprehensive coverage.

item.title: Resource Allocation & Task Prioritization
item.description: Concerns were raised about managing time and resource allocation, particularly balancing revenue-generating tasks with organizing the SharePoint site.

item.title: Resource Allocation & Task Prioritization
item.description: Final thoughts on prioritization underscore the urgent need to set clear priorities and receive direction on which tasks have higher immediate value. The speaker plans to use the next 10 minutes to clarify their own plan and priorities before the meeting.

item.title: Resource Allocation & Task Prioritization
item.description: The speaker noted that both tasks cannot be completed simultaneously, emphasizing that this is impossible given their work style.

item.title: ðŸ“… Next Steps
item.description: [ ] Clarify priorities between revenue-generating activities and SharePoint site restructuring.

item.title: ðŸ“… Next Steps
item.description: [ ] Determine if a contractor is needed for SharePoint restructuring and initiate the hiring process if necessary.

item.title: ðŸ“… Next Steps
item.description: [ ] Build an organizational chart in SharePoint as requested by Marissa.

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: Issues include confusion over document locations, inconsistent communication, and increased risk exposure due to the difficulty in knowing where information and documents reside.

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: External sharing has grown exponentially since 2023; while some is justified, much poses significant HIPAA and security risks, requiring better control.

item.title: # Current State and Challenges
item.description: Example: A financial document was created outside its secure finance folder, leading to increased visibility and reduced security, highlighting the need for a more organized audit process.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: Limit external sharing to only those who require it (e.g., investor relations needing to communicate with 200 investors); restrict for clinical staff to comply with HIPAA, as their client-related sharing should occur via secure email or Kifu.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: Conduct regular audits and utilize reports to monitor site activity, data volume, and relevance, including utilization stats and last use dates to identify unused sites.

item.title: # Proposed Vision and Solutions
item.description: **Structural Overhaul**

item.title: # Data, Facts, and Examples
item.description: **Audit and Inventory**

item.title: # Data, Facts, and Examples
item.description: The challenge of consolidating or migrating information from potentially 500 existing email groups/SharePoint sites.

item.title: # Data, Facts, and Examples
item.description: Reference to a previous consulting engagement with Able Consulting in 2023 for SharePoint/intranet design, indicating prior exploration of solutions.

item.title: # Conclusions
item.description: The current SharePoint environment is fragmented, insecure, difficult to navigate, and has grown "rogue" without sufficient control.

item.title: # Conclusions
item.description: There is consensus on the need for a more structured, department-based and process-based site architecture anchored by a central home site (intranet).

item.title: # Conclusions
item.description: Security, compliance (especially HIPAA), user adoption, and clear communication are primary concerns that must be addressed.

item.title: ðŸ“… Next Steps and Action Items
item.description: [ ] Distribute an Excel spreadsheet inventory of all current SharePoint sites, groups, and folders for review, shared on SharePoint and via APN email for collaboration.

item.title: ðŸ“… Next Steps and Action Items
item.description: [ ] Include utilization reports (activity, data volume, last access, member count) with the inventory spreadsheet to guide cleanup and prioritization.

item.title: ðŸ“… Next Steps and Action Items
item.description: [ ] Solicit feedback and contributions from team members on the inventory document to identify relevance and impact of existing sites.

item.title: # Travel and Scheduling
item.description: A meeting is scheduled for the 24th of this month at the Lodge. Booking and organization for this meeting are currently underway, with the speaker planning to book it today and send out messages.

item.title: # Travel and Scheduling
item.description: An upcoming trip to Florida with Lee is scheduled, departing early Thursday, with activities planned for both Thursday and Friday.

item.title: # Telehealth and Admissions Update
item.description: Telehealth activity is increasing, specifically with more TIOP (Telehealth Intensive Outpatient Program) cases coming in, indicating a positive trend.

item.title: # Telehealth and Admissions Update
item.description: Robin successfully admitted a client with an eating disorder background, leveraging her expertise in that area, which signifies growth in this specific segment.

item.title: # Telehealth and Admissions Update
item.description: Vicki had a strong previous month and continues to perform well. Lee is also actively networking and generating referrals, with the expectation that her efforts will lead to more clients as people start talking.

item.title: # Account Management and Winback Strategy
item.description: A new, organized Winback account list has been created, which is categorized by account name and owner within Salesforce. This list was recently organized to be more effective.

item.title: # Account Management and Winback Strategy
item.description: The list tracks crucial metrics such as admits, opportunities, and the last referral dates for each account, allowing for efficient filtering by account owner, such as Desiree or Craig.

item.title: # Account Management and Winback Strategy
item.description: It has been identified that some accounts, like Mountainside and Dylan, may be miscategorized and require verification and correction to ensure accurate assignments.

item.title: # Communication and Discharge Process
item.description: Discharge paperwork should be sent to parents if they have complete medical oversight, particularly in cases like Bradley Benson where clients cannot manage their own records. The speaker is "90% sure" this is permissible.

item.title: # Communication and Discharge Process
item.description: There is significant frustration with delays in communication, particularly when clients have signed releases. The expectation is for immediate communication once a release is signed, without further internal deliberation.

item.title: # Communication and Discharge Process
item.description: Recent issues have arisen with Valiant requesting paperwork for referred clients, highlighting the critical need for discharge paperwork to always be available, especially for high-end or concierge clients.

item.title: # Process Improvements and Tools
item.description: This process improvement is expected to launch within the next 30 days, aiming to streamline the entire process.

item.title: # Process Improvements and Tools
item.description: An upcoming implementation involves a "quick card," also referred to as a "Jason card," within Teams. This tool will allow therapists to document specific recommendations (e.g., PHP IOP for a certain duration) for clients, streamlining communication with finance and other departments regarding collection.

item.title: # Recruiting and Staffing
item.description: There is a clear need for more representatives, specifically on Desiree's side of things and in Dallas.

item.title: # Recruiting and Staffing
item.description: Kyle has been identified as a strong candidate for a new rep role. He is described as a "worker" and "team player" with existing experience and valuable contacts in areas like Ventura (where he lives), Santa Barbara, San Francisco, and Colorado, including connections like Cheyenne from Vail Health.

item.title: # Recruiting and Staffing
item.description: A proposal suggests assigning Kyle to Northern California and VA accounts, potentially with the title "Director of Community Relations, California/VA" or "West" to encompass a larger area, including California VAs and Utah VAs.

item.title: # Account Ownership and Performance Tracking
item.description: The importance of tracking account assignments and performance over time was emphasized, using the ERC account as an example for reassignment and follow-up. A formula suggests accounts that can refer monthly should be touched at least once a month.

item.title: # Account Ownership and Performance Tracking
item.description: A plan is in place to have Micah create a dashboard to monitor account touches and referral activity over the last three months. This tool will help identify underperforming accounts and optimize rep efforts by showing how many times an account has been touched and if it's time to move on.

item.title: # Marketing and Conference Planning
item.description: The estimated budget for these marketing materials is close to $10,000. It is recommended to spread this cost over three months, allocating approximately $3,000 per month.

item.title: # Marketing and Conference Planning
item.description: The plan is to prioritize purchases and sequence spending over the next 90 days based on immediate needs.

item.title: # Marketing and Conference Planning
item.description: For conference participation, a booth at a September event where Phillip and Amy are speaking costs $1,500. While sponsorship was considered, the preference is for a table-only presence, as conference sponsorships are often not memorable.

item.title: # Team Management and Communication
item.description: The short-term admissions goal for the entire team (excluding Nicole) is 20 admits per month, an increase from the current 17.

item.title: # Team Management and Communication
item.description: A plan is to schedule weekly 30-minute one-on-ones with all representatives, preferably back-to-back on Fridays, to streamline the process.

item.title: # Team Management and Communication
item.description: During these one-on-ones, reps will receive the win-back list and review their weekly meetings and next steps.

item.title: # Miscellaneous
item.description: Lee and Robin are noted for being responsive and following directions well, which has contributed positively to telehealth admissions.

item.title: # Miscellaneous
item.description: The speaker is actively managing ongoing marketing efforts and conference logistics until these processes are fully established within the role.

item.title: # Miscellaneous
item.description: Coordination with Jess and other marketing contacts is ongoing to ensure that marketing materials are procured cost-effectively and are not overpriced.

item.title: Financial and Operational Updates
item.description: Current census is low (about 48), but daily revenue remains strong due to high daily rates, making more money than at a higher census of 68.

item.title: Financial and Operational Updates
item.description: Despite lower census, financial performance is improving (e.g., highest monthly cash collection of $3.5 million, with expenses around $4 million, and labor costs significantly down).

item.title: Feedback on Personnel and Clinical Contributions
item.description: A Washington PHP doctor (Dr. Sack) praised the teamâ€™s competence and effectiveness, calling them the "absolute best" and "most talented team."

item.title: Feedback on Personnel and Clinical Contributions
item.description: Clinical staff, such as Dr. Sack, provide timely return-to-work evaluations, offer teaching, explain complex drug screen results, and understand the professional program's return-to-work protocols (e.g., half-time work, reassessment after eight weeks).

item.description: Positive clinical feedback:

item.title: Observations on Meeting Effectiveness and Coaching
item.description: Coaching and mentoring:

item.title: Observations on Meeting Effectiveness and Coaching
item.description: One leader coaches less assertive managers (e.g., Sims) to balance therapeutic engagement with decisiveness, helping them manage emotions and maintain a positive outlook in crisis situations.

item.title: Observations on Meeting Effectiveness and Coaching
item.description: Highlights differences between results-driven and relational management styles, emphasizing that staff are either "detractors or contributors."

item.title: # Financial Management and Variance Collection
item.description: The primary focus is on actively collecting a variance to meet a targeted daily rate at any level of care.

item.title: # Financial Management and Variance Collection
item.description: There is a strong emphasis on learning from past experiences, as the past has led to nothing but financial distress.

item.title: # Financial Management and Variance Collection
item.description: A robust recommendation is made to question any preconceived beliefs or practices that were previously communicated, particularly concerning finances and the collection of less money. The speaker addresses "Desiree" directly in this context.

item.title: # Communication and Support
item.description: Assurance is provided that the feedback is not intended to be critical or accusatory, with the speaker stating, "I am not being hard on anyone and I am not pointing the finger at anyone."

item.title: # Communication and Support
item.description: Encouragement is given to reach out with any other questions or concerns.

item.title: # Communication and Support
item.description: Openness to communication is strongly emphasized, with a clear reminder to never hesitate to reach out for clarification or support.

item.title: # Closing Remarks
item.description: The recording features multiple expressions of gratitude and thanks, including "Thank you" and "Thanks for watching!".

item.title: # Closing Remarks
item.description: A friendly and supportive tone is maintained throughout the communication, concluding with a distinct "Mwah!" sound.

item.title: Blue Cross Blue Shield Lawsuit & Data Analysis
item.description: **Technical Solution:** Seeking a developer (a former employee described as a brilliant guy who wrote his own cryptocurrency, never left the house, still lives with his mom, is about 30 years old, and is considered a 'secret weapon' for his ability to find anything on the internet) to write a script for every Blue Cross Blue Shield facility.

item.title: Blue Cross Blue Shield Lawsuit & Data Analysis
item.description: **Objective:** Demonstrate Blue Cross Blue Shieldâ€™s lack of network adequacy, focusing on patients traveling out of state for treatment.

item.title: Project Overview
item.description: Emphasis on leveraging publicly available data, specifically the national provider database, to support an $80 million lawsuit involving Blue Cross Blue Shield. This data is considered crucial for legal standing, as Blue Cross and similar companies are mandated by the Data Transparency Act to publish accurate information.

item.title: Project Overview
item.description: Identification of targeted provider registry data, including machine-readable files and provider details with MPI (National Provider Identifier) and taxonomy codes.

item.title: Project Overview
item.description: Focus on precise provider mapping, filtering by specific taxonomy codes to isolate relevant facilities, primarily substance use disorder facilities.

item.title: Data and Technical Requirements
item.description: A notable failed attempt involved using a Python script, generated by ChatGPT, to extract files from Alabama; this script ran for 90 minutes before ultimately failing due to memory constraints.

item.title: Data and Technical Requirements
item.description: Extraction of provider registry data, confirmed to be a completely free dataset that covers the entire inspection of providers.

item.title: Data and Technical Requirements
item.description: Data filtering based on client-supplied taxonomy codes is essential to narrow the list, specifically excluding multi-specialty clinics and focusing on two primary taxonomy codes, including one for substance use disorder facilities and another for primary mental health.

item.title: Work Process and Technical Approach
item.description: Proposal to utilize an existing Maptiv account for visualizing the provider registry data, leveraging its pre-built base map for efficiency and ease of use.

item.title: Work Process and Technical Approach
item.description: Integration of multiple data sources, including insights from a shared GitHub project for a provider database, although this specific project has limitations in mapping due to latitude and longitude restrictions.

item.title: Work Process and Technical Approach
item.description: A key plan is to create a heat map visualization, segmented into three distinct colors by taxonomy, to facilitate easier identification of in-network versus out-of-network providers and assess network adequacy.

item.title: Payment Structure and Agreement Details
item.description: The project is proposed to operate on an hourly basis, with an initial block cap set at 50 hours.

item.title: Payment Structure and Agreement Details
item.description: The estimated rate for this block is $3,000, with an understanding that flexibility will be applied if unforeseen technical limitations (such as bandwidth or processing constraints) arise, ensuring payment up to the hours logged if the project needs to stop.

item.title: Payment Structure and Agreement Details
item.description: Consideration will be given to drafting a formal statement of work or agreement to structure the project professionally, especially for potential future collaborations.

item.title: Additional Considerations
item.description: Discussion included the potential use of an API for Blue Cross Blue Shield data extraction if available, or otherwise relying on public provider registry data mandated by Data Transparency Acts.

item.title: Additional Considerations
item.description: A significant concern regarding the MPPI dataset's legal validity was raised, as it primarily provides a list of providers but does not confirm whether they are actively offering services in-network, necessitating a second phase of scraping to validate service provision.

item.title: Additional Considerations
item.description: The possibility to shift focus to alternative datasets, such as state licensure data, was discussed as a contingency if Blue Cross-related scraping becomes too complex or fails to yield accurate network adequacy data. For example, the lack of subacute mental health licenses in states like Texas could form a basis for a legal case, as patients may have no in-state options for certain types of care.

item.title: ðŸ“… Next Steps
item.description: [ ] The consultant will confirm acceptance of the 50-hour block assignment and the associated $3,000 rate for the project.

item.title: ðŸ“… Next Steps
item.description: [ ] The client will provide specific taxonomy codes for substance use disorder facilities and primary mental health, explicitly excluding multi-specialty clinics.

item.title: ðŸ“… Next Steps
item.description: [ ] The client will share Maptiv account login details for mapping and visualization purposes.

item.title: Claims Analysis and Filing Strategy
item.description: Most claims are concentrated in Colorado, making it the primary focus for analysis and legal action.

item.title: Claims Analysis and Filing Strategy
item.description: Additional internal analysis will be conducted to confirm the extent and specifics of claims, especially in Colorado.

item.title: Claims Analysis and Filing Strategy
item.description: The timeline for processing Colorado claims will determine the overall opportunity size and subsequent steps for filing.

item.title: Data Visualization Requirements
item.description: Visualizations (maps) are intended for a judge as part of an injunctive hearing, focusing on injunctive relief due to financial distress caused by non-payment.

item.title: Data Visualization Requirements
item.description: Visualizations should be professional and clear, suitable for a legal audience.

item.title: Data Visualization Requirements
item.description: Standard heat maps or dot maps are acceptable; mimicking official forestry or state map styles is recommended for normalization to the judge.

item.title: Deadlines and Deliverables
item.description: If the initial data is inadequate, further information may be required before proceeding, as insufficient data could lead to the case being dismissed by the judge, potentially risking an $80 million claim.

item.title: Deadlines and Deliverables
item.description: The absolute deadline for deliverables is not fixed but should ideally be within the current week, though it depends on the completeness of the data.

item.title: Deadlines and Deliverables
item.description: Deliverables include:

item.title: Communication Preferences
item.description: Text messaging is preferred for urgent or important communications, as emails may be overlooked.

item.title: Communication Preferences
item.description: A statement of work and a quote will be provided as soon as possible.

item.title: Legal and Process Considerations
item.description: The case is being prepared for an injunctive hearing.

item.title: Legal and Process Considerations
item.description: The internal general attorney will make the final decision on filing based on the data presented.

item.title: Legal and Process Considerations
item.description: The process will proceed step by step, adapting as more information becomes available.

item.title: ðŸ“… Next Steps
item.description: [ ] Complete further internal analysis on claims, focusing on Colorado.

item.title: ðŸ“… Next Steps
item.description: [ ] Prepare and deliver professional visualizations (heat map/dot map) with source documentation.

item.title: ðŸ“… Next Steps
item.description: [ ] Provide multiple visualization options for review.

item.title: Balance Sheet Reconciliation and System Integration
item.description: Scott is verifying subledgers, such as cash tied to bank accounts, and ensuring key accounts (revenues, AR reserves, AP) reconcile, impacting the P&L.

item.title: Balance Sheet Reconciliation and System Integration
item.description: SAGE and NetSuite balances must match, with the primary focus on finalizing the balance sheet as of May/June.

item.title: Balance Sheet Reconciliation and System Integration
item.description: Rye is ensuring SAGE balances align with NetSuite across multiple entities (e.g., Malibu, Naples, Boulder).

item.title: Deferred Revenue and Allocation Process
item.description: Deferred revenue refers to cash received before it is earned (unearned revenue), distinct from accruals for earned revenue.

item.title: Deferred Revenue and Allocation Process
item.description: NetSuite holds the deferred revenue figure, which must reconcile with Sage using a subledger or schedule to identify the source/customer.

item.title: Deferred Revenue and Allocation Process
item.description: Allocation training is needed, as cash allocation is currently manual due to staff not knowing how to process this in Sage.

item.title: Cash Flow Reporting and Forecasting
item.description: A weekly cash flow report will be generated using the RISE file as the source of truth, but improvements are needed in communication (assumptions, top spend details) and visual tools like a 13-week projection graph.

item.title: Cash Flow Reporting and Forecasting
item.description: Forecasts are compared by reviewing forecasted versus actual collections (targeting 94â€“95% accuracy) and analyzing forecasted volumes.

item.title: Cash Flow Reporting and Forecasting
item.description: Call volume is the leading indicator, with plans to use six weeks of historical data (doubled for a 13-week forecast).

item.title: Month-End Close Process Improvements
item.description: Scott may shift from cash management to focus on SAGE implementation support and controlling tasks D1â€“D6.

item.title: Month-End Close Process Improvements
item.description: Historical month-end close challenges stemmed from the SAGE transition and prior checklist inefficiencies.

item.title: Month-End Close Process Improvements
item.description: A detailed checklist (used before SAGE reconciliation issues) outlines items to be completed by specific business days.

item.title: Accounts Payable and Vendor Expense Controls
item.description: Discussion centered on disorganized expense tagging and allocation in the general ledger.

item.title: Accounts Payable and Vendor Expense Controls
item.description: Power Query is used to categorize transactions by department, criticality, and necessity, ranking expenses (e.g., food cost per patient day, auto floor expenses) and flagging items for cancellation or review.

item.title: Accounts Payable and Vendor Expense Controls
item.description: Tags must be aligned across systems (clinical, administrative, nursing costs) to ensure accurate departmental allocations.

item.title: Integrating Business Intelligence (BI) and Real-Time Reporting
item.description: Planned BI enhancements include granular reports by expense category (fixed, variable, semi-fixed) and tracking KPIs (e.g., per patient day revenue, food cost optimization) operationally.

item.title: Integrating Business Intelligence (BI) and Real-Time Reporting
item.description: The goal is to integrate Sage with BI via API for near real-time financial data updates.

item.title: Integrating Business Intelligence (BI) and Real-Time Reporting
item.description: A sample NetSuite integration (from an external analytics partner) demonstrated how data and GL classifications can be visualized in BI dashboards.

item.title: Operational and Staff Capacity Considerations
item.description: The long-term vision is to increase capacity by transitioning to a fractional CFO model with clearer reporting lines and board communication.

item.title: Operational and Staff Capacity Considerations
item.description: The team is operating near maximum capacity, limiting support for additional projects. Discussions are underway to leverage current staff and new hires (e.g., Plutus for AR) to reduce workload.

item.title: Operational and Staff Capacity Considerations
item.description: Contract documentation and general ledger reviews are centralized in shared folders for transparency and regular departmental review.

item.title: Process Automation and Future Reporting Enhancements
item.description: Ongoing improvement is expected through regular meetings with facility leads (weekly or bi-weekly) to monitor KPIs and enforce cost controls.

item.title: Process Automation and Future Reporting Enhancements
item.description: A demonstration showed how general ledger data is transformed via Power Query to produce categorized expense reports.

item.title: Process Automation and Future Reporting Enhancements
item.description: The report ranks vendor expenses so departments can identify critical versus non-critical spending, aiding decisions on delaying or canceling expenses.

item.title: Roles, Hours, and Communication Guidelines
item.description: The consultant is currently committed to 25 hours per week, with flexibility to adjust as needed, aiming to streamline financial processes and reduce senior management workload.

item.title: Roles, Hours, and Communication Guidelines
item.description: Financial analysts (including Scott and Rye) are aligning responsibilities, with Scott focusing on SAGE implementation support and others handling cash management.

item.title: Roles, Hours, and Communication Guidelines
item.description: Communication protocol: CC on emails means â€œfor your information,â€ while tagged emails require immediate action.

item.title: # Current Workload and Client Updates
item.description: Speaker 1 has been very busy, with approximately eight clients recently leaving, many described as "needy."

item.title: # Current Workload and Client Updates
item.description: Speaker 1's ongoing duties include teaching, graduation programming, and general alumni engagement at "the lodge."

item.title: # Current Workload and Client Updates
item.description: Speaker 1 is actively managing a busy week with client transitions and new client interest, indicating a good but demanding period.

item.title: # Alumni Engagement and Content Strategy
item.description: Speaker 1, currently "Director of Alumni Programs," is considering a title change to "Senior Director" or "Senior Director of Programming," noting that a long title isn't necessary for feeling valued.

item.title: # Alumni Engagement and Content Strategy
item.description: Speaker 1 proposes creating content (e.g., for Instagram or YouTube) to maintain alumni connections, viewing it as a "value add" to their job.

item.title: # Alumni Engagement and Content Strategy
item.description: The upfront cost would be minimal, requiring only a small handheld camera, as Speaker 1 is already present at "the lodge" and can video and edit.

item.title: # Strategic Planning and Organizational Goals
item.description: A strategic planning meeting is scheduled for the week of the 21stâ€“24th (Speaker 2 initially thought 21st-23rd, then corrected to 22nd-24th), involving out-of-town participants.

item.title: # Strategic Planning and Organizational Goals
item.description: Speaker 2 aspires for the organization to be recognized as the best treatment center in Colorado, though acknowledges not everyone would give a "resounding yes." Speaker 1, however, believes they are the best treatment center in Colorado, period.

item.title: # Strategic Planning and Organizational Goals
item.description: Weaknesses include the IOP program needing help and readmissions being a concern for Speaker 2.

item.title: # Compensation and Role Expansion
item.description: Speaker 1 lost approximately $30,000/year due to the discontinuation of "six west," which was a yearly amount.

item.title: # Compensation and Role Expansion
item.description: Speaker 1's current salary is $95,000/year.

item.title: # Compensation and Role Expansion
item.description: Speaker 1 is seeking a compensation adjustment to recover this lost income, referencing another employee, Major, who went from $90,000 to $135,000 after their first promotion.

item.title: # Business Development and Market Presence
item.description: Speaker 2 intends to leverage Speaker 1's skills for BD in important cities, potentially by having Speaker 1 do BD one day a week.

item.title: # Business Development and Market Presence
item.description: The current BD rep's underperformance is noted, and Speaker 2 confirms they are hiring someone else, having shown the current rep a map of their assigned territory (colored zip codes with 16.5-mile radii around two sites).

item.title: # Business Development and Market Presence
item.description: Speaker 1 noted that the previous BD rep, Desiree, despite personal issues, did get people into "the launch."

item.title: # Operational Feedback and Process Improvement
item.description: Alumni frequently report difficulty contacting the finance department post-discharge, with Speaker 1 receiving daily questions about it.

item.title: # Operational Feedback and Process Improvement
item.description: Speaker 1 suggests streamlining communication, possibly by ensuring case management has finance emails, to smooth out this process.

item.title: # Operational Feedback and Process Improvement
item.description: Speaker 2 has a meeting scheduled with the finance department next week to understand their operations, noting that finance is not consistently billing or collecting money from all clients, including on the back end of treatment.

item.title: # Scalability and Future Planning
item.description: Speaker 1 currently manages extensive outreach, monthly follow-ups, phone calls, and support calls (e.g., a 6:30 am call for short-term disability paperwork).

item.title: # Scalability and Future Planning
item.description: The alumni engagement workload is increasing as the program grows, requiring consideration of scalability.

item.title: # Scalability and Future Planning
item.description: Potential solutions include additional staff (e.g., a "mini Nicole" to learn the ropes) or technology (e.g., an app), with technology being viewed as the "cheapest FTE" in Vail, Colorado.

item.title: # Recognition and Organizational Culture
item.description: Speaker 2 recognizes Speaker 1 as a "bright spot" and a key asset in the organization, particularly for alumni engagement, noting Speaker 1's ability to work with clients and provide "street cred."

item.title: # Recognition and Organizational Culture
item.description: Speaker 2 emphasizes leveraging Speaker 1's strengths and passion for client care, noting Speaker 1's belief in the organization as the best treatment center.

item.title: # Recognition and Organizational Culture
item.description: Speaker 2 desires to formalize event planning and engagement responsibilities to maximize Speaker 1's talents, potentially by having Speaker 1 book a certain number of meetings or close deals.

item.title: Definitions and Classifications
item.description: **"Unable to disclose"**: The insurance company explicitly refused to provide the information.

item.title: Definitions and Classifications
item.description: **"Unknown"**: No contact could be made with the insurance company to obtain the information. It was also suggested and agreed upon to reclassify this status as â€œnot yet identifiedâ€ for improved clarity.

item.title: Definitions and Classifications
item.description: **"Paid to subscriber"**: Indicates that the claim was paid to the client, confirmed once the Explanation of Benefits (EOB) is received.

item.title: Spreadsheet and Data Management
item.description: The spreadsheet contains a complex dataset with about 22,000 lines.

item.title: Spreadsheet and Data Management
item.description: The creation of this spreadsheet was noted as one of the most challenging tasks undertaken at APN, providing significant learning opportunities, including identifying inefficiencies.

item.title: Spreadsheet and Data Management
item.description: Detailed explanations for claim statuses are included alongside the data.

item.title: Network Adequacy Map and Data Mapping Process
item.description: NOAA requested a network adequacy map, which involves managing large datasets (about 10GB per state).

item.title: Network Adequacy Map and Data Mapping Process
item.description: Extensive research has been conducted to ensure the defensibility of the approach, and the mapping process itself is estimated to require about 50 hours of work.

item.title: Network Adequacy Map and Data Mapping Process
item.description: The process includes pulling data from the National Provider Registry, cross-referencing taxonomy codes, and mapping these to Blue Cross MPI numbers.

item.title: Project Development and Financial Considerations
item.description: There is a verbal agreement for an additional $6,000 cost, verified by Katrina.

item.title: Project Development and Financial Considerations
item.description: The developer is responsible for processing the network adequacy map on a state-by-state basis.

item.title: Project Development and Financial Considerations
item.description: The initial phase will focus on mapping for Colorado, after which a decision will be made on expanding to other states.
